comments:
Now, I'm using BIRT 2.1.0-final and I'm afraid of migrating to latest version... I'm tring to use a simple stored procedure in Oracle as a data set. I've already searched bugzilla and the newsgroups but didn't find anything simmilar. I have a different problem than the ref cursor one that have been solved in the last version.

My procedure is the following:

create or replace PROCEDURE EQUIP_PATH_TO_ROOT
(equip_tree_id IN INTEGER DEFAULT 0, path OUT VARCHAR) AS
  curr_node_id INTEGER;
BEGIN
  curr_node_id := equip_tree_id;
  LOOP
    SELECT tree.parent_id, type.name || '/' || path INTO curr_node_id, path 
    FROM EQUIPMENTS_TREE tree
    INNER JOIN EQUIPMENTS_TYPE type ON tree.equipments_type_id = type.id
    WHERE tree.id = curr_node_id;
    EXIT WHEN curr_node_id = 0 OR curr_node_id IS NULL;
  END LOOP;
END;

It runs correctly in oracle!

In the designer I select "SQL Stored Procedure Query" and than
call my procedure like this: 
{call equip_path_to_root(?, ?);}

Than I describe my parameters as follows:
Name, Data Type, Direction, Default Value
EQUIP_TREE_ID, INTEGER, INPUT, 165
PATH, String, OUT, 

When I press "Preview output parameters" I get the following error:
Error Message:Cannot execute the statement.
SQL statement dose not return a ResultSet object or an update count.
SQL error #1: Unsuported feature

The driver I use is ojdbc14_g.jar, oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver (10.2).

I have a huge number of reports and thats the reason I don't want to upgrade to latest version. Though, I have a bad experience migrating from previouse versions and I'd rather not suffer that again. However, please if this is fixed in the last version let mi know!

Try remove the semicolon from {call equip_path_to_root(?, ?);}
I was curious about the SQL error #1: Unsuported feature though, could you attach the error stack trace as well please

I did replaced the semicolon but situation remains the same.
Full stack trace is:

After checking the code, I suspect it's the driver that cause the problem.
I am afraid it's not easy to put the explanation in a short manner and not sure if you are interested so I would recommend you change the driver first, it should work.
Where did you get the driver anyway?

I did changed the driver from: http://www.oracle.com/technology/software/tech/java/sqlj_jdbc/htdocs/jdbc_10201.html
but the problem still remains. My DB version is: 
Oracle Database 10g  Release 2 (10.2.0.2) JDBC Drivers.

I was wondering what driver are you using and where can I get it....

I did changed the driver from: http://www.oracle.com/technology/software/tech/java/sqlj_jdbc/htdocs/jdbc_10201.html
but the problem still remains. My DB version is: 
Oracle Database 10g  Release 2 (10.2.0.2) JDBC Drivers.

I was wondering what driver are you using and where can I get it....

Sorry for the late reply due to the network failure
for the same reason I currently cant link to the site you provided
However, like I said, there might be a bug in the latest jdbc driver offered by oracle,try an older one.

As it's not really a bug to me, I am closing it as worksforme
Feel free to leave messages though if you have further question, thanks
